titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.36 (30 Aug-6 Sept 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 36 Mercurius Publicus, COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence: WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order. From Thur≈øday Augu≈øt 30. to Thur≈øday Septemb. 6. 1660.
Am≈øterdam, Augu≈øt 21.
div.p: THe Po≈øt of O≈ønabrug reports, that about ≈øix days ≈øince ≈øome of the Garri≈øon of Mun≈øter, after they had been very merry the night before, made a Sally out of that City, when they were yet half drunk, taking in a ≈ømall Fort which the Bi≈øhop had cau≈øed to be rai≈øed for the blocking up of the Place, and putting ≈øome men in it to maintain it; But as they returned back to the City, the Bi≈øhops Hor≈øe ‚Ä¢ ell in upon the rear of them, and killed about thirty men, among whom one of the Burgoma≈øters was found. The Bi≈øhop had cau≈øed ≈øome of the Citizens that were killed, to be hanged up.

body.head: A Letter from Major Robert Holmes, Commander of the Heneretta, ≈øent unto Baron Battavella in Spain.
body.p: BEing appointed by comm ‚Ä¢ nd from His Royal Highne≈øs the Duke of York, to wait on Your Excellency with one of His Maje≈øties Ships, the King of Great Britain, I think it fit to let Your Excellency know‚ñ™ That I am ≈øafely arrived upon the Coa≈øt, and intend to Anchor at Gatharia Road, where I hope to hear from you, and in order thereunto have ≈øent my Ketch, to bring Your Excellencies commands. I did intend to put in to Pa≈ø≈øage; but finding the entring of the Harbour ≈øo narrow, I dare not venture with a Ship of this concernment without Your ≈øpecial Order; and if Your Excellency think not this place convenient, be plea≈øed to appoint any other, and I ≈øhall immediately ≈øet ≈øail towards it, if wind and weather will permit. The enclo≈øed Letters were given me by Count Con≈øtang, and Mon≈øieur de Ovietta: I ≈øhall humbly beg Your Excellencies pardon for not waiting on you with them my ≈øelf.

closer.signed: My Lord, Your Excellencies mo≈øt affectionate and humble Servant, Robert Holmes.
closer.dateline:
From on Board the Heneretta, off of Cape Martin Chegoe,
Aug. 8. 1660.

div.p:
On wedne≈øday the 22. of Augu≈øt, the Earl of Glencairn, Lord Chancellor of Scotland, came into this City honourably attended by about 1000. Hor≈øe. The Major General, Colonell Daniel, and Colonell Di≈øne the Engli≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners, with ≈øeveral Field-Officers, and two Troops of the
Major Generals Regiment of Hor≈øe, went to Mu≈øsleborough to meet his Lord≈øhip, and attended him thence to the Hou≈øe de≈øigned for his Lord≈øhip in this City. At his coming in to Edinborough, the Earle of Winton rode on his right hand, and Major General Morgan on his left: He was guarded from the Water-gate to the Nether-Bow, by the Major Generals Regiment of Foot. The Lord Chancellor being come the Committee of three E≈øtates (according to the late Proclamation) ≈øate on Thur≈øday, Aug. 23. and information being given of ≈øome Remon≈øtrating Mini≈øters that were at Robert Sym≈øon, the Collectors hou≈øe; Orders were ≈øent to Captain Newman in Edinborough Ca≈øtle, to command thence 20. Mu≈øquetiers to Sym≈øon's hou≈øe, who found the Mini≈øters ≈øub≈øcribing a Paper tending to the di≈øturbance of this Kingdom. The Mini≈øters were carryed Pri≈øoners to Edinborough Ca≈øtle: Their names are
Mr. James Guthrie, Mini≈øter of Sterling.
Mr. Robert Trayle, Mini≈øters of Edinborough.
Mr. John Strivling, Mini≈øters of Edinborough.
Mr. Alexander Moncreif, Mini≈øter of Scooney.
Mr. John Semple, Mini≈øter of Carffern.
Mr. Thomas R ‚Ä¢ m≈øey, Mini≈øter of Foulden.
Mr. Gilbert Hall, Mini≈øter of Kirkli≈øton.
Mr. John Scot, Mini≈øter at Ornham.
Mr. George Nairne, Mini≈øter at Brunt I≈øland.
Mr. John Murray, Mini≈øter of Maffin Pari≈øh.
James Kirk, Laird of Soudaywell.
Whereupon the Lord Chancellor with the Committee of the Three E≈øtates, the very next day ≈øet forth this following Proclamation.

body.head: A Proclamation by the Committee of E≈øtates convened by His Majesties ≈øpecial Authority, against unlawfull Meetings and ≈øeditious Papers.
body.p:
THe Committee of E≈øtates in obedience to His Maje≈øties Proclamation being met, and taking to their ≈øe
‚Ä¢ ou ‚Ä¢ con≈øideration the goodne≈øs of God, who in his great mercy hath re≈øtored the Kings Maje≈øty to the Exerci≈øe of ‚Ä¢ is Royal Government; And withall, con≈øidering His ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ je≈øties great care of, and affection to this His Maje≈øties Anc ‚Ä¢ ent Kingdom of Scotland, in Calling and Authorizing the ≈øaid Committee of E≈øtates to Meet; And they finding it their duty to prevent all unlawful Meetings, which may tend to the prejudice of His Maje≈øties Service, or may again involve His Maje≈øties good Subjects into new Troubles; Have thought it fit in His Maje≈øties Name and Authority, to prohibite, And by the≈øe Pre≈øents do prohibite and di≈øcharge all unlawful and unwarrantable Meetings or Conventicles in any place within this His Maje≈øties Kingdom of Scotland, without His Maje≈øties ≈øpecial Authority; And likewi≈øe all ≈øeditious Petitions and Remon≈øtrances, under what pretence ≈øoever which may tend to the di≈øturbance of the Peace of this Kingdom, or alienating and debauching the affections of His Maje≈øties Subjects from their due obedience to His Maje≈øties lawful Authority, and that under all highe≈øt pains. And for this effect, appoints all Sheriffs of Shires, and Magi≈øtrates of Burghs to be careful within their re≈øpective Bounds, that no ≈øuch pernicious and dangerous meetings be permitted, but that they be timeou≈øly prevented, hindered, made known and di≈øcovered to the Committee
of E≈øtates. And ordain the≈øe pre≈øents to be forthwith Printed, and Publi≈øhed at the Mercat cro≈øs of Edinburgh, and the Head Burghs of the re≈øpective Shires within this Kingdom, that none pretend ignorance hereof.

closer.signed: Signed in the Name, and by Warrant of the Committee of E≈øtates. GLENCARNE Chancellour. I. P. D. Com.

div.p: After which was ≈øet forth another Proclamation commanding that no Di≈øorders of In≈øolencies be committed by any per≈øon whatever within this Kingdom upon any of the Engli≈øh Nation, under all highe≈øt pain, after which they adjourn'd till Tue≈øday following.

div.head: White-Hall.
div.p: His Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to confer the Honour of Knight-hood upon Herbert Perrot, E≈øquire, a worthy Member of the Hou≈øe of Commons, ≈øerving in Parliament for the Burrough of Weobly, in the County of Herreford.

On Thur≈øday la≈øt that accompli≈øhed Per≈øonage George Earl of Bri≈øtol, entertain'd His Maje≈øty at his own hou≈øe with a Supper, with whom was Their Royal Highne≈ø≈øes the Dukes of York and Glouce≈øter, attended by the Marque≈øs of Ormond, and other Per≈øons of Honour.

On Friday the Lords had a Conference with the Commons, wherein Their Lord≈øhips acquainted the Commons with His Maje≈øties Me≈ø≈øage for an Adjournment from the eighth of September to the ≈øixth of November next.

The Dani≈øh Emba≈ø≈øadours who lately arrived here out of Holland, are this day gone by land for Denmark. The Imperial Field-Mar≈øhal Montecuculi, is daily expected here. Two days ago arrived here from Sweden, the Pa ‚Ä¢ sgrave of Su ‚Ä¢ zhach, and the Prince of Anha ‚Ä¢
; they intend to ≈øtay here ≈øome few days, to wait on the Queen of Sweden, and then to return into Germany. The confederate Forces are now at la≈øt broke up in Hol≈øten, being appointed to quarter this night at Rensburgh, and to morrow at New Mini≈øter; and tho≈øe 600 hor≈øe which were ≈øaid to continue in Hol≈øten, are likewi≈øe to withdraw on the 21 in≈øtant, and to follow after the re≈øt. The Imperial hor≈øe which were quartered in Meklenburg, are already drawn together in order to their ≈øpeedy march out of that country, and the Foot is to follow them within a fortnight. The Ratifications of peace with the Emperor, Sweden, Poland, and Brandenburg, are mutually exchanged and delivered at Danzick, on the ≈øixth and eighth courant, and Elbing is to be delivered up to the King of Poland on the 14. of this moneth. What other place will be given for it to the Elector of Brandenburg, is not yet certainly known; Field-Mar≈øhal Schack is made a Senator of the Kingdom of Denmark, and Major-General Eggerick is appointed Governour of Copenhagen. The Parliament in Sweden is to A≈ø≈øemble on the 21 of Septemb. and the Ceremonies of the late Kings Funeral are to be performed in the moneth October following; which when done, ≈øeveral Emba≈ø≈øies are to be di≈øpatched thence for England, France, Holland and other places.

Letters which the la≈øt Po≈øt from Gratz, intimate, that his Imperial Maje≈øty was to proceed on his journey for Carin
‚Ä¢ hia and
‚Ä¢ rain at the beginning of the next moneth, accompanied
only with few of his Court, and re≈øolved to go ≈øo far as Trie≈øt on the Adriatick Sea coa≈øt, where the V ‚Ä¢ netians are a preparing of ≈øeveral Nav ‚Ä¢ l diverti≈øemen ‚Ä¢ s and curio≈øities, to entertain his Maje≈øty; which it ≈øo, then his Maje≈øties return would not he ≈øo ≈øudden as otherwi≈øe was expected. The Venetians pur≈øue their Lev ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ in the≈øe parts, with much eagerne≈øs, and get a number of good Souldiers of the Bava ‚Ä¢ ian di≈ø-banded Forces into their ≈øervice. The E≈øtates of Nether-Au≈øtria are to A≈ø≈øemble here the next week: We are adverti≈øed from Hungaria, that the Count of Serin, upon Order from his Imperial Maje≈øty, hath withdrawn his Forces from the Fort of Cani≈øcha.

div.head: Venice, Augu≈øt 6.
div.p: Two of our Gallies, with many armed B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ kes, are lately arrived at Ancona; the Turki≈øh Pyrates upon information hereof, retreated out of the Gulf with their Booty: But others are ≈øince gone to the I≈øle of Elba, where they have plundred the Town of Piumbino, and carryed away many ≈ølaves, together with the Nuns of the Cloi≈øter in that place. The Turks having received a ≈øupply of 4 ‚Ä¢ 0 hor≈øe in Canea, they have ≈øo far made their approaches to the City of Candia, that they begin to annoy it with ≈ølinging of fire into it; But ours, to relieve the place, have drawn their Forces together about Cerigo. Here arrived lately a Turki≈øh Gally, which was ma≈øtered by 170 Slaves, who all had their liberty and a piece of money given them.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE Due way of Compo≈øing the Differences on Foot, Pre≈øerving the Church. According to the Opinion of Herbert Thorndike: Sold by John Martin, James Alle≈øtry, and Thomas Dicas, at the Bell in St. Paul's Church-yard.

div.head:
Hague,
September 20. S. N.
div.p: The Lords States of the Province of Zealand, to the number of twenty ≈øix, having been fetched up with ≈øeveral Coaches to their audience with the Lords States of Holland, Mon≈øieur Adri ‚Ä¢ n Vet, Pen≈øioner of the States of Zealand, made a very eloquent and large Speech, wherein he remon≈øt ‚Ä¢ ated to them, tho≈øe motives and rea≈øons which induc'd his Principals to ≈øettle and e≈øtabli≈øh the Government of the≈øe Provinces upon their ancient Foundation, under a Lieutenant or Captain Admiral General, for which tru≈øt they had nominated his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, according to their re≈øolution taken on the ≈øeventh of this moneth, de≈øiring the States of Holland would be plea≈øed to concur with them therein: In order whereunto, a conference is to be held b ‚Ä¢ tween the Deputies of tho≈øe two States, to endeavour a joynt conde≈øcen≈øion to, and ratification of the premi≈øes. What the re≈øult of it will be, a ≈øhort time mu≈øt di≈øcover. There is no certainty yet of the Amba≈ø≈øadors going hence for England, and it is thought that they can hardly have their di≈øpatch the≈øe ≈øix weeks.

div.head: An Extract of the Re≈øolution taken by the Lords States of the Province of Zealand on Saturday the ≈øeventh of Augu≈øt, S. N. concerning his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange.
div.p: 1. That the Prince of Orange, in behalf of this Province, together with the other Confederates of the A≈ø≈øembly of their High and mighty Lord≈øhips the States General, ≈øhall be cho≈øen and nominated Captain and Admiral General of the United Netherlands, with a convenient Commi≈ø≈øion and In≈øtructions to be agreed and concluded upon between the ≈øeveral Provinces, and a yearly revenue of 100000 Gilders for his maintenance, to be levied upon the States account, and to begin from the time the Commi≈ø≈øion is i≈ø≈øued out.

2. To which purpo≈øe, certain Deputies are to be appointed by this a≈ø≈øembly, to repair to the a≈ø≈øembly of the Lords States General, to tender to their Lord≈øhips this point of electing a Governor, and with the be≈øt rea≈øons to procure their con≈øent, and a ≈øpeedy effect of it.

3. That a tender of the charge of Governor, Captain and Admiral-general of both the Provinces, be pre≈øently made to his Highne≈øs the ≈øaid Prince of Orange, with a convenient Commi≈ø≈øion and in≈øtructions to be i≈ø≈øued out without delay, to which the Lords States of Holland are to be required to give their concurrence, that ≈øo in regard of their
common intere≈øts, and according to antient practice, this affair may be determined pari pa≈ø≈øu, and with joint advice; and that a Commi≈ø≈øion be drawn and ≈øealed, as it was done in the year 1647.

4. Yet in ca≈øe this appointment of the Prince for the abovementioned places ≈øhould not take effect with the Lords States General, and the States of Holland, contrary to the expectation, wi≈øh and good intention of this a≈ø≈øembly, that then, upon a full report of their Deputies concerning their negotiation, this A≈ø≈øembly will take care, and order affairs ≈øo, as may mo≈øt tend to the honor, welfare and ≈øervice of the country.

5. It is the unanimous con≈øent of the ≈øaid Lords States of Zealand, that the beforementioned Prince of Orange ≈øhall not exerci≈øe tho≈øe eminent charges of General and Admiral≈øhip, till his Highne≈øs come to be eighteen years of age; which charges (during his minority) are not to be executed by any under the name of Lieutenant, but remain as now they are, which two conditions are to be expre≈øly in≈øerted in the beforementioned Commi≈øsion.

6. That pre≈øently by an unanimous con≈øent and appointment of all the Members a≈ø≈øembled, the dignity and place of the Fir≈øt Noble ≈øhall be pre≈øented to the Prince, he being the mo≈øt con≈øpicuous and qualified Nobleman of this Province; yet upon ≈øuch clau≈øes, re≈øtrictions and precautions, as the ≈øame dignity hath been heretofore conferred upon the Princes of Orange of immortal memory, without diminution or prejudice of the priviledges of this Province, and other the ≈øeveral Members of this State.

7. Upon the conferring of ≈øuch charges, Honors and preheminences on the ≈øaid Prince, all po≈øsible care and order ≈øhall be taken for his Highne≈øs Education and Breeding, as may be≈øt befit his Princely per≈øon and Illu≈øtrious Family.

8. That his Highne≈øs ≈øhall be allowed at the 16. year of his age, to have acce≈øs to the Council of State, according as it was practi≈øed by his Highne≈øs Grand-Father Prince Frederick
Henry, that ≈øo his Highne≈øs may be in≈øtructed in the Fundamental Laws and Maximes, and the Antient and Renowned Government of the≈øe Countries, and the better learn the humor and inclinations of his good people and Countrymen.

div.head: Adverti≈øements of Books newly Printed and Publi≈øhed.
div.p: ‚òûPhil-Anglus: Some ≈øober in≈øpections made into the carriage and con≈øults of the late long Parliament: whereby occa≈øion is taken to ≈øpeak of Parliaments in former tim ‚Ä¢ s, &c. With ≈øome reflexes upon Government in general. With ≈øome Prophetick Paragraphs. By James Howel E≈øq. Sold by W. Palmer at the Palm-Tree near St. Dun≈øtans Church in Fleet≈øtreet.

Five Sea≈øonable Sermons Preached before eminent Auditories, and Dedicated to the Kings Maje≈øty, by Paul Knell, Ma≈øter in Arts of Clare-Hall in Cambridge, ≈øometime Chaplain to a Regiment of Cura≈ø≈øiers in his late Maje≈øties ‚Ä¢ rmy. Sold by John Place at Furnivals Inn-Gate in Holborn.

div.head: Adverti≈øement.
div.p: IF any man can give notice of a light Dun Mare with a bald face, and four white feet, black mane and tail, a lock of white hairs in her tail, about ≈øeven years old, and about fifteen hand high, that was taken out of a Stable in Coale Yard on Thur≈øday Augu≈øt 30. by a young man about 27. years of age, brown hair, ≈øomewhat l ‚Ä¢ ng, of a pale complexion and round face, with a pla≈øter on the left check. If any one apprehend him, and give notice at the Red Lion in Cambridge, the Cro ‚Ä¢ s Keys in St Edes, or the Holy Lamb on the back≈øide of St. Clements, they ≈øhall have five pound for their pains.

STolen the ≈øecond of September, out of a Dining-Room in Holborn, one large Looking Gla≈øs ≈øet in an Ebony frame, a Landskip being drawn at the tom of the gla≈øs, with a Shepherde≈øs, a ‚Ä¢ am ‚Ä¢ , a G ‚Ä¢ at, and ≈øeveral other figures, there being a ≈ølaw at the top of the Gla≈øs, as al≈øo two Turkey Carpets, the one three yards long, and two yards and a half wide, or thereabouts; the other two yards and a half long, and a yard and a half wide, or thereabouts. If any one give notice thereof to ‚Ä¢ r. Arnold a Grocer, at the Tobacco-Roll and Sugar-Loaf next to Grais-Inn-Gate in Holborn, they ≈øhall have ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ty ≈øhillings for their pains.

ON Saturday l ‚Ä¢ ≈øt run away from the Lord Rich: Chri≈øtophilus Cornaro, a Turk Chri≈øtened: A French youth of 17 or 18 years of age, with flaxen hair, little blew eyes, a mark upon his lip, and another under his right eye; of a fair complexion, one of his ears pierced, having a Pearl-coloured Cloth ≈øuit, trim'd with ≈øcarlet and blew Ribbons, a Coat of the ≈øame colour, with ≈øilver Buttons, his name Iacob David. Give notice to the Lords Lodging at the 3 Fi≈øhes in New ‚Ä¢ reet in Covent Garden, a Cooks ≈øhop, and good ≈øatisfaction ≈øhall be given.

div.head: Adverti≈øements.
div.p: THe Reader is de≈øired to take notice, That his Maje≈øties Printers having publi≈øhed the Act of Free and General Pardon, Indempuity and Oblivion, in a more contracted Form then ordinary, that it might be of ≈ømall price; yet notwith≈øtanding ≈øome per≈øons have not only pre≈øumed to Re-print the ≈øame, to their very great detriment, but have al≈øo committed ≈øeveral gro≈øs faults, as in Page 5. they have left out (any of) Page 7. l. 11. (or Acquittances) Pag. 8. li. 19. (the day) li. 43. (Maje≈øties) left out. Pag. 12. (of) left out, and (or per≈øons) too much; be≈øides the≈øe Errata there are very many other Mi≈øtakes, which ought not to pa≈øs in a thing of ≈øo great con≈øequence. This ≈øtollen fal≈øe impre≈ø≈øion may be known, by being printed in three ≈øheets, not of the known Letter for Acts, whereas the right is Five ≈øheets; All Per≈øons therefore, who de≈øire a true Copy of the Act of Indempnity, are advis'd to beware of that fal≈øe imperfect Three ≈øheets, which will but deceive the Buyer.

RIchard Verney E≈øq of Alax≈øt ‚Ä¢ n in Leice≈øter≈øhire, about a for might ≈øince lo≈ø ‚Ä¢ a Lanner from that place, ≈øhe hath neither Bells nor Varvels; ≈øhe is a wh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Hawk, and her long feathers and ≈øar≈øcels are both in the blood. „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ give tidings thereof to Mr Lambert at the golden Key in Fleet≈øtreet, they ≈øhall have forty ≈øhillings for their pains.

THe But end and the Lock of a Gunn, commonly called a ‚Ä¢ taff Gunn, being dutch-worke, and fitted to its Barrel, with a Screw, within few ≈øuch ‚Ä¢ s of the touch-hole, was lo≈øt between London and Barnet on Tue ‚Ä¢ day 21 Augu≈øt: if any one do bring it to Sir Eliab Harveys Hou≈øe in Bread≈øtreet, he ≈øha ‚Ä¢ l have twenty ≈øhillings for his pains.

LO≈øt on Sunday night la≈øt, out of the King Meadows near King≈øton upon Thames, in the County of Surrey one brown bay Mare three years old and upward, having a white ≈øtar in the forehead, a white ≈ønip up ‚Ä¢ n the no≈øe, and a little white on one of her hind-feet, about 14 hands high, in good fl ‚Ä¢ ≈øh. Al≈øo a bright bay Mare, between 14 and 15 handfuls high, about 9 ye ‚Ä¢ rs old, a white ≈øtreak down the face, a white foot behind, and the near ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e of the other hind-foot, but meanly in fle≈øh. If any give not ‚Ä¢ ce to Henry Mudhets at the three Pigeons in King≈øton a ‚Ä¢ ore≈øaid; or to Mr. Bed≈øon a Tailor in New Street in Covent-Garden, they ≈øhall have forty ≈øhillings for their pains.

On Monday the third in≈øtant, the Accu≈øation again≈øt. Col. Robert Worden was taken into con≈øideration by his Maj ‚Ä¢ ≈øty ≈øitting in full Council, where was read a large Atte≈øtation under the hands of Sir George Boo ‚Ä¢ h and the greate≈øt part of the Baronets, Knights, E≈øquires and Gentlemen of the County
Palatine of Che≈øter, declaring that they ever found the ≈øaid Col. Worden in all his Maje≈øties concernments, not only faithful, but ≈øo indu≈øtrious and prudent, as that no Per≈øon would be more acceptable for their future Tru≈øt. Upon con≈øideration whereof, and that ≈øeveral Lords of the Council affirmed, that in the time of the late Tyrannical Government, the ≈øaid Colonel was highly in≈øtrumental to advance his Maje≈øties intere≈øt, and that by their communication with him, their Lives and Fortunes had been in his power; expre≈øsing their e≈øteem of him as of a Worthy and Loyal Per≈øon, his Maje≈øty declar'd that He did fully acquit him from the accu≈øation and and imputation he had ≈øuffered under, and that He e≈øteem'd him a very hone≈øt and Loyal Per≈øon, and would accord ‚Ä¢ ngly admit him into his former favor. In earne≈øt whereof his Maje≈øty hath given him the honor of his hand, and his Highne≈øs the Duke of York hath gladly received him into his Service, as formerly, to the joy of many worthy and valiant Per≈øons, who had long known the Colonels courage and loyalty, and were ≈øorry a mi≈øtake in others ≈øhould be get any ≈øu≈øpition upon a Per≈øon ≈øo highly de≈øerving.

div.head: We≈øtmin≈øter.
div.p:
And now we can tell News which all the good ≈øubjects of three Kingdoms will rejoice at; how that great In≈øtrument of ≈øedition and Firebrand, Hugh Peters, is clo≈øe pri≈øoner in the Tower of London. The particulars take impartially thus. On Friday la≈øt intelligence was given that Peters privily lurked about Southwark; whereupon Sir Edward Nicholas his Maje≈øties principal Secretary of State, ≈øent two Me≈ø≈øengers of his Maje≈øties Chamber in ordinary to apprehend him: That night they entred the hou≈øe where he lay, which was one Broad's a Quaker in S. Thomas pari≈øh, who≈øe daughter Mrs. Peach then l ‚Ä¢ y in. The Me≈ø≈øengers ≈øearch'd, but mi≈øs'd Hugh Peters, who (according to his cu≈øtom) had crept into bed to the young woman, where the Me≈ø≈øengers mode≈øty forbad their ≈øearch; ≈øhe having been delivered but two days before. There lay Hugh; and the Me≈ø≈øengers finding a private pa≈ø≈øage out of that into the hou≈øe of another Quaker call'd John Day the Cobler, (thus Quaking runs from hou≈øe to hou≈øe;) they ≈øearch'd there al≈øo: In the interim Peters e≈øcap'd from childbed, leaving behind him his Cane with a R ‚Ä¢ pier in it, a ≈ømall pocket-Bible, and a gray Cloak, (for po≈ø≈øibly now he was in his Frock.) But on Sunday la≈øt
about ≈øix at night, in a place call'd the Maze, in the ≈øame pari≈øh near Hor≈ø-way Down, at Nathanael Mun a Tape-weavers hou≈øe, Hugh Peters again lay in. The Me≈ø≈øenger Mr. Wickham coming to the door, found it not lock'd nor latch'd, but kept fa≈øt by the Tape-weavers wife, (how faithful that ≈øex are to Peters!) who thru≈øt her back to the door, till the Me≈ø≈øengers ≈øtrength prov'd Mrs. Mun was the weaker ve≈ø≈øel, and ≈øuddenly running up ≈øtairs, found that door al≈øo kept fa≈øt like the other: 'tw ‚Ä¢ s Hugh him≈øelf, who≈øe ≈øhoulder at the door put the Me≈ø≈øenger hard to it, for Peters now thought he thru≈øt for his life. But the Me≈ø≈øenger encourag'd, in hopes 'twas Peters, who≈øe ≈øtrength fail'd, as his fe ‚Ä¢ r increa≈øed, at la≈øt the door flew open, where Hugh Peters was found (a true Quaker) trembling after an incredible manner: Yet now (in his wonted way of confidence) he ≈øtifly denied him≈øelf to be Peters, but ≈øaid his name was Thomp≈øon (perhaps Hugh the ≈øon of Thomas) threatning the Me≈ø≈øengers with an Action at Law for offering to ‚Ä¢ ffirm he was Hugh Peters; and therefore refu≈øed to go down with the Me≈ø≈øenger, till Mr. Arnold (≈øervant to Mr. Blagge of his Maje≈øties Bedchamber) Mr. Hopkins a good neighbour, and Mr. Harris the hone≈øt Con≈øtable came up the ≈øtairs, who all expre≈ø≈øed much diligence and heartine≈øs in a≈ø≈øi≈øting the Me≈ø≈øenger. And yet after all, he refu≈øed to come down (≈øtill wondring they would think him Peters,) ≈øo as they began to force him down, and then he promi≈øed to go along, but fir≈øt, ≈øaid he, give me leave to gather up my ≈øpirits; whereupon he call'd for Drink, and drank two quarts (two full qu ‚Ä¢ rts) of ≈ømall Beer, for the Hou≈øe had no ≈øtrong. Then Hugh de≈øired he might ≈øpeak privately with Mris. Mun, which they denied, unle≈øs hee would ≈øpeak in their hearing; after which hee ≈øaid, I will go, but I beg for the Lords ≈øake that you call mee not Mr. Peters, for, ≈ø ‚Ä¢ id hee, if it be known that I am Hugh Peters, the people in the ≈øtreet will ≈øtone mee. At la≈øt out hee came, but ≈øuddenly ≈øtept in again, ≈øaying, I mu≈øt ≈øpeak privately with the woman of the Hou≈øe, (a woman was his chief Confident) and now they had ≈øome tugging to fetch him back, in which ≈øtruggle, feeling his skirts hard, they unrip ‚Ä¢ them, and found five peeces of Gold and ≈øome Silver Medals, and out of his pocket they took his Alm ‚Ä¢ nack, for which hee ≈øtruggled more than for his Bible. Thence they forced him to the Con≈øtables Hou≈øe, where they ≈øent for his Landlord Broad (an old Accu≈øer of hone≈øt men) who being ab≈øent, his Son-in-law Peach, (who≈øe happine≈øs it was that his Wife had been but „Äà‚óä„Äâ daies delivered) came in his ≈øtead, who being asked if hee knew that Cloak, Cane, and Gloves, an≈øwered, that they belongd to that Gentleman; pointing to Peters. But Hugh ≈øtill with his wonted mode ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y denied it, name and ‚Ä¢ ll; though ≈øoon
(forgetting him≈øelf) hee unawares put on the Gloves, and ≈øaid, they were his own; and then without more trifling they brought him to the Tower, and delivered him into the cu≈øtody of the worthy Lieutenant Sir Iohn Robin≈øon (in the blood of who≈øe Uncle, that ever-renowned William late Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, Hugh Peters was elbow deep, and go ‚Ä¢ the Archbi≈øhops Library of mo≈øt choi≈øe Books, as well as his Maje≈øties Library at St. James's) which he hath now turn'd to a pocket Bible and an Almanack. All this while, and at the Tower al≈øo, Hugh averred his name was Thom≈øon, and denied him≈øelf to be Peters though there his Co≈øin Mr. Birch the Wardour knew him and called the man by his name; til at la≈øt in privat to Sir Iohn Robin≈øon he confe≈ø≈øed who hee was, and then (with mo≈øt ingenious mode≈øty) acch≈øed the Me≈ø≈øenger and the re≈øt for taking and bringing him to the Tower by the name of Thom≈øon. So that he who before threatned an Action again≈øt tho≈øe who offered to call him Hugh Peters, doth now accu≈øe them for calling him Thom≈øon. This is St. Hugh, who when our Glorious Soveraign was led to Martyrdom, fel ≈øo he ‚Ä¢ vy upon his righteous ≈øoul, bla≈øpheming him upon his then Text (P≈øal. 149. To bind their Kings in Chains, &c.) and may now make him≈øelf the Title of his own Book (call'd Good work for a good Magi≈øtrate) where among m ‚Ä¢ ny other, he hath the≈øe ≈øix motions.

1. That Pauls Church may be pull'd down to pave Thame≈øtreet. 2. To d ‚Ä¢ ≈øtroy Colledges, ≈øince there are none in the Go≈øpel, pag. 4. (for Hugh was expelled one.) 3. That Phy≈øicians ≈øhould take ≈ømall fees, pag. 33. (What was Hugh's di≈øea≈øe?) ‚Äî 4. That Adultery ≈øhould be puni≈øhed with a merciful heart pag. 52. (and not like Butchers.) 5. That all unmarried maids be put to ≈øpin, (to prevent the be≈øt u≈øe of hemp.) 6. That all Records in the Tower might be burn'd‚ÄîBut the Records ≈øtill are ≈øafe in the Tower, and ≈øo is Hugh Peters, where now we leave him.

La≈øt Monday morning about eleven of the clock, that notorious John Harris (commonly called Major Harris) was executed in Leadenhall≈øtreet, over ‚Ä¢ gain≈øt the Merchants hou≈øe where he committed the Burglary by a forged Warrant in the Lord High Chancellors name. This is that Harris who h ‚Ä¢ d been Conductor to Oliver Cromwels Forces, and a frequent fal≈øe Witne≈øs again≈øt his Maje≈øties good Subjects.

On Sunday la≈øt his Maje≈øty went to Greenwich to refre≈øh him≈øelf for ≈øome few hours in that Yaugh which was pre≈øented to him from Am≈øterdam; which Yaugh or Plea≈øure-Boat will ≈øcarce be equalled by any in the≈øe parts of Chri≈øtendom.
On Tue≈øday (September 4.) the Lord Roberts Nobly entertained his Maje≈øty with a ≈øupper at his hou≈øe at Chel≈øey.
London, Printed by John Macock, and Tho: Newcomb 1660.
